questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?

options.option_text: JavaScript is a low level programming language.
The “const” keyword can be used to declare objects with block level scope.
Int, char are some primitive data types in the JavaScript language.
The JavaScript language supports both the first order and higher orderfunctions.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: A web application must implement token based authentication to make theapplication secure.
The JAMStack approach separates out the frontend from the backend, andthey both can be updated/modified independently without affecting the other.
It is recommended to avoid the usage of verbs in the API data URLs.
The idea behind bringing an API is to implement caching.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?

options.option_text: A Celery system can only use Redis as the message broker.
A Celery system may consist of a number of batch jobs.
A Celery system needs worker(s) to execute tasks.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?

options.option_text: The term “polling” generally refers to short polling.
Webhooks are used for 1 way communication, unlike web sockets.
In polling, the connection to the server is kept open, until the data is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?

options.option_text: Cookies are stored on the server.
Cookies are stored on the browser.
Browser sends the cookies to the origin server automatically in general.
Client has to include cookies manually with the request, in general.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?

options.option_text: It is a protocol to allow access to resources, hosted on a different server, onbehalf of a user.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?
question_texts: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?

options.option_text: Closure is the state of the outer function.
Closure is the state of a variable.
Closure is a function along with its lexical environment or surrounding state.
Closures are created every time a function is created in JavaScript.

The CORS mechanism allows a developer to secure a web application fromexternal origins.
The CORS headers are generally prefixed with the value “Access-Control-Allow”.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: The server sent events is a mechanism for a server to push events, and it mustrequire service workers on the client to function properly.
In general, a webhook is meant to pull message(s) from an application.
The usage of a message broker over “point-to-point” communication makesthe application scalable.
There is no difference between webhooks and short polling.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)

options.option_text: The approach 1 will wait for a user input before dispatching the task to thecelery system.
The approach 2 will dispatch the task to the celery system after waiting for 10seconds, and start the execution, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 2 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, butstart the execution after waiting for 10 seconds, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 1 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, andstart the execution, assuming a worker is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?

options.option_text: In general, an application should have separate Vuex stores for all thecomponents.
A path defined in the routes array in Vue router can consist of a number ofchildren paths.
The wildcard (*) should be put at the top of the routes array in the Vue router,so that it matches with all the paths, which are not implemented.
A Vuex store must be used with all Vue applications.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding fetch API?

options.option_text: The credentials property of the Request interface allows the user agent tosend or receive cookies in cross-origin requests.
The value “omit” of “credentials” will force the browser not to send cookies withthe request.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialseven in cross-origin requests.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialsonly for same origin requests.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?

options.option_text: The local storage is a browser based persistent storage.
Cookies are preferred over session or local storage, when the data needs to besent with every request.
The cookies can be set from the server as well as using javascript on the client.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and equations** for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- ## **Core Topics & Concepts** ### **1. JavaScript Fundamentals** - **Primitive Data Types**: No `int`, `char` (unlike Java/C). Only `number`, `string`, `boolean`, `null`, `undefined`, `symbol`, `bigint`. - **`const` vs `let`**: - `const`: Block-scoped, cannot be reassigned (but objects/arrays can be mutated). - `let`: Block-scoped, reassignable. - **First-Order vs Higher-Order Functions**: - **First-order**: Treated as variables (passed as args, returned from functions). - **Higher-order**: Take functions as args or return them (e.g., `map`, `filter`). - **Closures**: - A function + its lexical environment (surrounding state). - Created every time a function is defined. - Example: ```javascript function outer() { let x = 10; return function inner() { console.log(x); }; // Closure } ``` - **Promises & Async/Await**: - `.then()`: Handles resolved promises. - `.catch()`: Handles rejections. - `.finally()`: Runs regardless of resolution/rejection. - **Async/Await**: Syntactic sugar for promises. ```javascript async function foo() { let result = await promise; console.log(result); } ``` - **Truthiness & Operator Precedence**: - `||` (OR) returns the first truthy value. - `&&` (AND) returns the first falsy value or the last truthy. - Example: ```javascript let a = 2 * 4 || 0 / 4; // 8 (2*4 is truthy) let b = 3 * 4 && 0 / 4; // 0 (0/4 is falsy) ``` --- ### **2. Modern Web Development** #### **A. Authentication & Security** - **OAuth**: - **Authorization** protocol (not authentication). - Allows third-party access to resources without sharing credentials. - **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**: - Headers: `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`, `Access-Control-Allow-Methods`. - Prevents unauthorized cross-origin requests. - **CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)**: - Attack forces users to execute unwanted actions. - Mitigation: Anti-CSRF tokens (e.g., Django’s `{% csrf_token %}`). - **Flask does not enforce CSRF by default** (unlike Django). - **Tokens vs Cookies**: - **Tokens (JWT)**: Stateless, stored client-side (e.g., `localStorage`). - **Cookies**: Stored client-side but sent automatically with requests. - **Session Storage**: Cleared when tab closes. - **Local Storage**: Persists until manually cleared. #### **B. APIs & Communication** - **REST API Design**: - Avoid verbs in URLs (use nouns, e.g., `/users` instead of `/getUsers`). - **Caching**: Not the primary purpose of APIs (but can be implemented via headers like `Cache-Control`). - **Webhooks vs Polling vs WebSockets**: | Feature | Webhooks | Polling (Short/Long) | WebSockets | |------------------|------------------------|---------------------------|---------------------| | **Direction** | Server → Client (1-way)| Client → Server (pull) | Bidirectional | | **Protocol** | HTTP | HTTP | WS/WSS | | **Efficiency** | High (event-driven) | Low (repeated requests) | High (persistent) | - **Message Brokers (Redis + Celery)**: - **Celery**: Distributed task queue (needs a broker like Redis/RabbitMQ). - **Redis**: Can be used as a broker or cache. - **Tasks**: - `task.delay()`: Immediate execution. - `task.apply_async(countdown=10)`: Delayed execution (10 seconds). #### **C. Fetch API** - **Credentials**: - `credentials: "omit"`: No cookies sent. - `credentials: "include"`: Send cookies (even cross-origin). - `credentials: "same-origin"`: Default (only same-origin cookies). --- ### **3. Vue.js** #### **A. Core Concepts** - **Reactivity**: - `data()`: Reactive state. - `computed`: Cached derived state. - `methods`: Functions (not cached). - **Directives**: - `v-model`: Two-way binding. - `v-for`: Loop rendering. - `v-show`/`v-if`: Conditional rendering. - **Lifecycle Hooks**: - `mounted()`: Runs after DOM insertion. - `created()`: Runs after instance creation. - **Class/Style Binding**: ```html
``` #### **B. Components & Props** - **Props**: Pass data parent → child. - **Custom Events**: Child → parent communication (`$emit`). - **Slots**: Reusable templates. - **Dynamic Components**: ``. #### **C. Vue Router** - **Routes**: Defined in `routes` array. - **Dynamic Segments**: `:id` in paths (e.g., `/user/:id`). - **Nested Routes**: Children routes under a parent. - **Wildcard (`*`)**: Must be **last** in the routes array (matches unmatched paths). #### **D. Vuex (State Management)** - **Store**: Centralized state. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state changes. - **Actions**: Async operations (commit mutations). - **Getters**: Computed properties for store state. - **Example**: ```javascript mutations: { updateList(state, payload) { state.list = payload; } }, actions: { fetchData({ commit }) { api.getData().then(data => commit('updateList', data)); } } ``` #### **E. Vue CLI & Templating** - **`v-model`**: Binds to `localStorage` if manually implemented. - **`ref`**: Access DOM elements or child components. - **Custom Input Components**: Use `v-model` with `:value` + `@input`. --- ### **4. Asynchronous JavaScript** - **Event Loop**: Handles callbacks, promises, and async operations. - **`setTimeout`**: Non-blocking delay. - **Promise Chaining**: ```javascript promise .then(data => console.log(data)) .catch(err => console.error(err)) .finally(() => console.log("Done")); ``` - **Arrow Functions & `this`**: - Arrow functions inherit `this` from the parent scope. - Regular functions have their own `this`. --- ## **Key Equations (JavaScript)** 1. **Logical OR (`||`) & AND (`&&`)**: - `a || b` → Returns `a` if truthy, else `b`. - `a && b` → Returns `a` if falsy, else `b`. 2. **Promise Resolution**: - `resolve(value)` → `.then(value => ...)`. - `reject(error)` → `.catch(error => ...)`. 3. **Async/Await**: ```javascript async function foo() { let result = await promise; // Pauses until promise resolves return result; } ``` 4. **Array Methods**: - `map`: Transform array → new array. - `filter`: Return subset based on condition. - Example: ```javascript const squares = [1, 2, 3].map(x => x ** 2); // [1, 4, 9] const evens = [1, 2, 3].filter(x => x % 2 === 0); // [2] ``` --- ## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** ### **Graph 1: JavaScript Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[JavaScript] --> B[Primitive Types] A --> C[Functions] C --> C1[First-Order] C --> C2[Higher-Order] A --> D[Closures] A --> E[Asynchronous] E --> E1[Promises] E --> E2[Async/Await] E --> E3[Event Loop] A --> F[Operators] F --> F1[Logical OR/AND] F --> F2[Truthiness] ``` ### **Graph 2: Web Development Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Development] --> B[Authentication] B --> B1[OAuth] B --> B2[JWT] B --> B3[Cookies] A --> C[APIs] C --> C1[REST] C --> C2[GraphQL] C --> C3[Webhooks] C --> C4[Polling] A --> D[Security] D --> D1[CORS] D --> D2[CSRF] D --> D3[XSS] ``` ### **Graph 3: Vue.js Ecosystem** ```mermaid graph TD A[Vue.js] --> B[Core] B --> B1[Reactivity] B --> B2[Directives] B --> B3[Lifecycle Hooks] A --> C[Components] C --> C1[Props] C --> C2[Events] C --> C3[Slots] A --> D[State Management] D --> D1[Vuex] D --> D2[Pinia] A --> E[Routing] E --> E1[Vue Router] E --> E2[Dynamic Routes] E --> E3[Nested Routes] ``` ### **Graph 4: Asynchronous Patterns** ```mermaid graph TD A[Asynchronous JS] --> B[Callbacks] A --> C[Promises] C --> C1[.then] C --> C2[.catch] C --> C3[.finally] A --> D[Async/Await] A --> E[Event Loop] E --> E1[Macrotasks] E --> E2[Microtasks] ``` ### **Graph 5: Data Flow in Vuex** ```mermaid graph LR A[Component] -->|Dispatch| B[Action] B -->|Commit| C[Mutation] C -->|Update| D[State] D -->|Render| A D -->|Getters| E[Derived State] ```
